comment.author: 47572660@N08
comment._content: Did anyone notice? That's a bicycle racing track around the ground. I didn't know they raced there at all.

comment.author: 47572660@N08
comment._content:
Just found this on Wikipedia:
In 1896 the Ladies' Stand was opened, along with a concrete cycling track which circled the inside of the ground. One of the carpenters who built the formwork for the track was George Bradman, father of Don Bradman. In 1898 floodlights were built over the cycling track so that night events could be held. In 1904 the scoreboard was rebuilt at the top of The Hill and in 1909 the Sheridan Stand, named after Phil Sheridan, was opened at the southern end, replacing the earlier Smokers' Stand.

In the period up to World War I the SCG was used for a wide variety of sports including athletics, tennis, baseball, football and cycling. The cycling track however was removed in 1920. In 1924 Ned Gregory's scoreboard was closed and the concrete scoreboard at the back of the Hill opened.

comment._content: Also see this pic for which a date has been established - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3022876525/ ; or these T&CJ pics from 1902 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71520669 ; www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/3063952301/ ; and from 1904 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71506318 ; also see the various pics of the English team in Sydney in November 1901, and the pics taken during the England v NSW match played at the SCG - news.google.com/newspapers?id=xwFQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-5QDA...
